answers.answer: Cataracts are more common in diabetics that are not well controlled BUT they are more common in well controled diabetics than in the general population.  Cataracts are more common in type 1 than type 2 diabetes.One variable you have no control over is how long you've had diabetes. After 20 years virtually all type 1 and 2 diabetics have some diabetic complications.Life would be great (or at least not so suspenseful) if we knew 'what was around the corner'. Keep your A1C at 6 or less to minimize complications. 7 or more isn't good enough.JCH III MD

question: I am 26 years old and am currently in between cateract surgeries.  My opthamologist says that I am not developing any other eye disease (retinopathy etc.).  I was always under the impression that cateracts developed from out of control sugar levels, however, my A1C has always stayed between 6.5-7.5 for the last 5 years.  However, there was a period of 2 years or so before being diagnosed with type 1 diabetes that my A1C stayed around 10.  So my question is, am I really not doing as well keeping my sugars under control as I had thought?  or is this something that developed from previously not keeping my sugars under control.  Also, at this rate, are more complications most likely around the corner?
title: cortical cateract - other complications
